title: Janeane Garofalo Never Sold Out. What a Relief.
abstract: That concept might be the reason her trailblazing stand-up career has been overshadowed; it may also be the reason she’s still so sharp, our critic argues.
des_facet: Mr Show with Bob and David (TV Program)
Romy and Michele's High School Reunion (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Janeane Garofalo after a show in Brooklyn. In the ’90s she played a crucial role in turning stand-up comedy away from the polished, tight sets ready-made for a sitcom or TV appearance.

title: Meryl Streep’s One Weird Trick
abstract: The dramatic removal of eyeglasses is a cinematic cliché. On Streep, it’s a revelation.

title: Barbara Kruger: A Way With Words
abstract: She created some of the most memorable works of her era. Now the activist-artist is back with two immersive shows, at MoMA and David Zwirner Gallery.

multimedia.caption: A view of Barbara Kruger’s vertiginous, loquacious new installation that engulfs the atrium of the Museum of Modern Art.
multimedia.copyright: Charlie Rubin for The New York Times

title: A Photographer Follows Paul Revere Williams Into the West
abstract: The architect’s achievements transformed the landscape of Nevada but were obscured by racism. Janna Ireland’s exhibition changes that.

title: Revisiting the Pyramids’ ‘Avant-Garde African Jazz,’ Four Decades Later
abstract: The group that started at Antioch College in Ohio went to Africa and returned “transformed,” one of its members said. A new boxed set collects its little-heard albums from the 1970s.

multimedia.caption: Margaux Simmons, left, and Idris Ackamoor in San Francisco during 1975 rehearsals for the Pyramids’ third album, “Birth/Speed/Merging.”
Margaux Simmons, left, and Idris Ackamoor in San Francisco during 1975 rehearsals for the Pyramids’ third album, “Birth/Speed/Merging.”
Margaux Simmons, left, and Idris Ackamoor in San Francisco during 1975 rehearsals for the Pyramids’ third album, “Birth/Speed/Merging.”

title: Avignon Festival Gets Its Buzz Back
abstract: With striking premieres in the main program and enchanting discoveries on the supplementary Fringe, the eminent event in European theater is flourishing after some difficult years.

multimedia.caption: Jean-Christophe Dollé and Clotilde Morgiève in “Phone Me,” directed by Clotilde Morgiève and Dollé.

title: How the Colorful Costumes of ‘Thor: Love and Thunder’ Were Made
abstract: “The Phantom of the Opera,” “Big Trouble in Little China” and an archaeology museum all played a part, the designer Mayes Rubeo explains.

multimedia.caption: Marvel gave the costume designer Mayes Rubeo visual parameters, “which I respect very much,” she said. “But it all goes a little bit out the window” when Taika Waititi is the director.
Marvel gave the costume designer Mayes Rubeo visual parameters, “which I respect very much,” she said. “But it all goes a little bit out the window” when Taika Waititi is the director.

title: Hidden Artwork Revealed by X-Ray Appears to Be Van Gogh Self-Portrait, Experts Say
abstract: A conservator at the National Galleries of Scotland uncovered the painting on the back of another one by the Dutch artist.

multimedia.caption: The painting remains hidden under cardboard and has been viewed only as an X-ray since it was discovered.
The painting remains hidden under cardboard and has been viewed only as an X-ray since it was discovered.
The painting remains hidden under cardboard and has been viewed only as an X-ray since it was discovered.

title: Kevin Spacey Pleads Not Guilty to Sexual Assault
abstract: The Oscar-winning actor will face a trial in June 2023 — a rare example of a celebrity #MeToo case reaching that stage in Britain.

multimedia.caption: The actor Kevin Spacey arrived for his appearance at the Old Bailey, a courthouse in central London.
The actor Kevin Spacey arrived for his appearance at the Old Bailey, a courthouse in central London.

title: black midi Bristles at a Bleak World With ‘Hellfire’
abstract: The British trio’s third studio album is a virtuosic exploration of brutality that showcases its technical mastery, expanded orchestrations and sardonic humor.

multimedia.caption: From left: black midi’s Geordie Greep, Cameron Picton and Morgan Simpson. The band’s tastes include prog-rock, post-punk, pop, funk, jazz, contemporary classical music, cabaret, electronics, flamenco, noise and more.

title: Review: In ‘The Rehearsal,’ All the World Is Staged
abstract: The docu-comedy chaos agent Nathan Fielder returns, testing the idea that practice makes a perfect life.

title: ‘Persuasion’ Review: The Present Intrudes Into the Past
abstract: Dakota Johnson smirks her way through a Netflix adaptation of the rekindled romance in Jane Austen’s last novel, our critic writes.

title: ‘Marx Can Wait’ Review: A Director Digs Into His Brother’s Death
abstract: In a moving new documentary, the Italian filmmaker Marco Bellocchio gathers his fascinating, aging family members to make sense of their brother’s suicide.

multimedia.caption: Three of the Bellocchio brothers, from left: Marco, the filmmaker; Alberto; and Camillo, who killed himself at 29. In “Marx Can Wait,” the family’s surviving members delve into Camillo’s death.

abstract: A traumatized star is supernaturally primed for vengeance in this gorgeously ghostly thriller.

title: ‘Top Gun: Maverick’ Enters the Pantheon of Conservative Fan Fiction
abstract: The American right has embraced Tom Cruise’s latest blockbuster, hailing the movie as a patriotic gesture produced in defiance of “woke” liberal elites and the Chinese Communist Party.
byline: By Blake Hounshell and Marc Tracy

multimedia.caption: In “Top Gun: Maverick,” Tom Cruise trains a group of young pilots for a dangerous mission against an unidentified hostile country.

title: Jerome M. Eisenberg, Expert on Antiquities Both Real and Fake, Dies at 92
abstract: He saw himself as a leader in promoting the ethical acquisition of ancient art by museums and collectors, although he also called himself “both an idealist and a hypocrite.”
des_facet: Destruction of Cultural Antiquities and Heritage

multimedia.caption: The antiquities dealer Jerome M. Eisenberg in 2004 with a selection from his stock of ancient military helmets. He sold an estimated 40,000 ancient artifacts over the years, and insisted that he never knowingly sold any that were of suspect provenance.

The antiquities dealer Jerome M. Eisenberg in 2004 with a selection from his stock of ancient military helmets. He sold an estimated 40,000 ancient artifacts over the years, and insisted that he never knowingly sold any that were of suspect provenance.

The antiquities dealer Jerome M. Eisenberg in 2004 with a selection from his stock of ancient military helmets. He sold an estimated 40,000 ancient artifacts over the years, and insisted that he never knowingly sold any that were of suspect provenance.

title: Monty Norman, Who Wrote 007’s Memorable Theme, Dies at 94
abstract: He composed the instantly recognizable melody for the first James Bond film, “Dr. No.” It has accompanied the agent on his adventures ever since.

multimedia.caption: The opening credit sequence of the first James Bond film, “Dr. No.” Monty Norman’s “James Bond Theme” captured the public imagination.

title: ‘From Where They Stood’ Review: Auschwitz, as Seen by Prisoners
abstract: Christophe Cognet’s documentary pores over photographs, some of them clandestine, taken by prisoners, inside the Nazi concentration camp.

multimedia.caption: In one clutch of images, prisoners displaying wounds on their legs are revealed to be subjects of Nazi medical experiments.
In one clutch of images, prisoners displaying wounds on their legs are revealed to be subjects of Nazi medical experiments.

title: ‘Where the Crawdads Sing’ Review: A Wild Heroine, a Soothing Tale
abstract: Daisy Edgar-Jones stars as an orphaned girl in the marshes of North Carolina in this tame adaptation of Delia Owens’s popular novel.

multimedia.caption: Daisy Edgar-Jones’s Kya is an irresistible if not quite coherent assemblage of literary tropes. Abused and abandoned, she is like the orphan princess in a fairy-tale.
multimedia.copyright: Michele K Short/Columbia Pictures/Sony Pictures Classics

title: A Mother’s Secret
abstract: He always thought his father was the only one at fault. Until one day, deep into adulthood, his mother asked him if they could go on a walk.

title: Computers and Painting’s Identity Crisis
abstract: A show at Nahmad Contemporary is an outgrowth of debates around “tradition” in art. Can artists embrace beauty while reaching for new technology?

title: ‘Desperate Characters’ and the Chaos That Lies Beneath
